title: Making your app feel faster than it really is

rawLines.text: Welcome to Syntax. Today we're talking
about how to make your app feel faster
than it actually is. So, we're talking
UI improvements, little tips and tricks
that you can do to make your app feel
faster. There's certainly we've talked
about how to actually make your website
faster. We've talked about that quite a
bit, but perceived speed is actually
really important when you're talking
about UI and talking about performance.
So, we're going to go through a whole
list of things you can do to improve the
perceived speed of your website.
Welcome, Scott. What's up? Hey, I got to
say, if if your website feels faster,
doesn't that mean it's actually
faster? You know, because like that's I
mean, we can measure numbers and
whatever that it took this amount of
time to load, but like isn't it all
about how it feels? I think it's all
about how it feels. That's that's where
I'm at. Yeah. Well, like if it is
faster, it feels faster. But if it's the
same speed, but it feels faster. It's
faster. It's faster. They're both to me,
these are both two two sides of the same
coin. And I think they're both valuable
techniques to have in your tool belt.
You know what else is a valuable tool in
your tool belt is Sentry because Sentry
does more than just tell you if your
application is broken. It also tells you
if your application is slow or if it
feels slow. because you get all kinds of
insights in in terms of being able to
see just how fast your app is at any
given point. You can assess the user
misery score for uh how just how fast or
slow this thing is for the majority of
users. And it gives you a nice little
user misery bar to say, hey, these are
the pages on your site that are slow and
potentially have a lot of traffic. So,
this is what you should be looking at.
And then you can further dive into all
right well what exactly is taking so
long to load on these pages? What are
what are the things? What are the
aspects? Where do I even start? Are
there errors? Right? You can you can you
know connect all of those dots together
and really understand the visibility.
You know who's getting a bad experience,
why and fix it because that's ultimately
what we're about here. So check it out
at ad
centry.io/sax. Sign up using the coupon
code tasty treat, all lowercase, all one
word, and get two months for free. This
podcast is presented by Century.
[Music]
Let's get into it. Let's get into it.
First one we have here is using a mouse
down or probably should be using a
pointer down event versus a click. Now,
this is not always a good idea,
and certainly I got a lot of people
angry on Twitter about it. Um, but the
the trick here is is that you can fire
things off when somebody mouses down or
or touches the screen versus when they
let go. A click is registered when you
let go. A a touch is registered when you
you let go. So, if you listen for the
initial start or down, you can make
things feel much faster. So, uh, Adam
Wan of Tailwind tweeted the other day
that he couldn't figure out why his
select drop downs just felt slower than
all the other UI libraries out there.
And it turns out they were the only one
listening for click. The rest of them
were listening for pointer down events
or mouse down or touch start events. So,
that's very important. that can make it
feel much faster because you you fire
off whatever it is you want right away.
It can also be really bad UX as well
because often I find myself if it's like
a button where you want to navigate
somewhere, I'll find myself touching it
and then if you drag your your finger
off or if you accidentally touch
something just with your finger, that
shouldn't necessarily always register an
actual action, right? There's this weird
thing with uh with iOS. Apparently iOS
still has a 40 millisecond delay in in
firing off a click event. Um for the
longest time we use this thing called
fast click where if you wanted to like
for example like check boxes, right? Uh
if you want to tap like three check
boxes, you just want to go boom. Like
that's you're really quick at that. And
often if there is a a delay in
registering that click or that that
touch touch event then you might hit it
twice because you think it didn't
actually do it and that's very
frustrating UX. So certainly with all
the
caveats be be very careful with this one
but it is used by lots of websites out
there you might not even realize. Yeah,
I I think this all goes back to the idea
of when you touch something, when you
click it, the the website should respond
instantly or as fast as possible to
anything that you're doing in an
interaction. And there's several
different types of issues that could be
at play for why that might feel slow,
some of which we'll talk even more about
later on in this episode. But just that
like when you click something, the
website should respond. And if you click
something and have to wait a second
before the page does something or
whatever, that makes normal users feel
like the thing is broken, like I clicked
it. What's happening? It's also one of
those things that makes the the website
feel like it's worse than a native app.
many of the things that we're trying to
like approach with like native apps is
that they're considered to be faster,
smoother, whatever, not just because of
60 frames per second, but because almost
always when you tap something, something
happens, right? And so that that's a big
part of it. Another one here is that
animations should be fast. And it's not
like every animation. There's certainly
some animations that can be slower or

defaulted
to 3 seconds for all of my transitions
and animations.
Since moved that to 2. Yes, I have since
I d I was like, you know what, whatever
it is, dial it back one more. Because a
lot of people they they fall in love
with the fact that the thing is
animating and they want to see that

yeah, that's a great users don't have
time for that." And for the most part,
you want your animations to be speedy.
Definitely something that you don't want
to take a second, half a second, any of
that stuff, you know, no, you know, 2/10
of a second probably fine. Yeah. If you
think about if you want to do several
things very fast, whether it's let's say
you want to open up three boxes and and
each of those takes an animation, right?
300 milliseconds to click. So that means
you're clicking three boxes. It takes
you a full second to click three boxes
whereas like you could probably tap or
click those in I don't know how long,
but not not a second. You could do it
much faster. Um, so just start with like
0.1 point 2. It depends obviously what

entire thing, that's probably much uh
can can be longer, but these like micro

fast and or even like entirely taken

there's no animation at all. It simply
just pops happens. Yeah, you click the
finder icon, finder pops up. And and I
think that is a big thing is that
animations certainly are great for a
number of things, but not everything. I
I do like one of the my big pet peeves
is like when you have a hamburger menu
and you click it and it's
like like okay, we did it. I just want
the menu to open and like give me give
me a two10 or one10 second animation on
that thing and call it a day. I I don't
have time to sit here and wait for your
hamburger menu to open. Yeah, on that
same point, animation should be like
cancelable. One that drives me crazy is
Spotify. If you want to view our stats
on the Spotify podcasters, you open up

all, you should be able to select custom

I have to click the arrow and I have to
wait until the animation finishes and
then click it again because if I click
it too quickly, it either breaks the
entire thing to reload the page or it
just doesn't react to to the click as
well. So, if there is an animation in
flight and somebody hits that thing
again, especially like you open
something and you go, "Oh, I didn't mean
to do that." And you quickly hit the the
close button. Yeah. That should react to
the action immediately. I also have this
on Instagram all the time where you ever
accidentally open an ad on like an
Instagram story. Oh, yeah. Yeah. You
know what I do? I just I quit the app.
I'm just like, I'm I'm sick of this. You
know, it's such a flow breaker. I could
watch an hour's worth of stories and I
accidentally touch an ad and it just
opens like that in browser web thing and
you can't click X fast enough because
the X is in the top leftand corner. You
know why? I can't reach it with my
thumb. I'm too lazy. I just I quit the
entire app and I hope that their stats
show that I'm I'm doing that. I sadly I
think you're probably the exception
there because I I agree. I'm the same
way. I I hate that stuff. And one thing
about animations being cancelellable and
reversible, another tip with this too is
that it should be the visual aspect of
it should be reversible. Too oftent
times what people do with this kind of
stuff is they have an opening animation
and a closing animation. The opening
goes from 0 to 100, the closing goes
from 100 to zero. So if you cancel it,
it's going to jump up to 100 and then go
to zero rather than, you know, if you
click cancel at 50%, it should stop at
50% and go back to zero. Like it should
not start at the end point of the
animation. It should start where you
are. Mhm. I agree. Yeah. And and
just reverse itself out from there.
Yeah. Skirt. Yeah, for sure.
Let's talk about an optimistic UI.
Optimistic UI is one of these things
that can do what we said just a moment
ago and make your application uh respond
the moment that you touch something. So
too often times what we're doing is you
click a button to perform an action, it
goes off and does some kind of fetch or
does some kind of data call, it hits the
API, it hits a server or something. That
thing takes who knows how long. could
take a little bit of time, a lot of bit
of time, even even like 400
milliseconds. Like you add something to
a list and it needs to refresh the list.
You're sitting there being like, did it
work? Did it work? And so the right
answer isn't to put a loading screen
here or anything like that. The right
answer is to perform the update to the
UI the moment that you click something
like the moment I hit enter. Perform the
update to the UI and then send that
information to the server in the
background. And then once that
information comes back, what you're
doing is you're either responding to an
error state and saying, "Oops, like
something failed and removed the one
from the list or whatever." Or you're
just now in the current state that
you're in. Like if you're using an each
loop with some ids and you update that
data in any of the modern frameworks,
it's not going to rerender that thing.
So what you'll want to do is like let's
say I'm adding something to to a to-do
list. I hit enter. the framework even
before it kicks off that API call should
be adding that text to the list of data.
That way it pops in immediately and then
the the this is called optimistic UI. Uh
a number of like frameworks have this
kind of thing built in. So if you're
looking to see if your data fetching
loading framework has it in it's going
to be called optimistic UI. But this is
one of those things that can make such a
big impact in having your app feel more
native. Yeah. And uh even one step
further than optimistic UI and I know
you'll like this one is don't have an
optimistic UI and just save the data
locally and use a sync engine. Yeah,
like the whole idea behind local first
is that you just store the data locally.
There's no need to to wait around,
right? You get rid of loading states,
you get rid of uh optimistic states. It
simply just immediately updates and then
and then the sync engine will will
update it in the background. Yeah. And
so optimistic UI is kind of like local
data light where you are handling just
that data change right and and you're
moni but with with local data you're
essentially caching that data on device
in a database. So therefore even on page
refresh it's going to be instantaneous
or as fast as it possibly can be and
then again on a change it's
instantaneous or as fast as it can be
and then everything else happens in the
background. It's just wonderful delay
loading indicators if something happens
quickly. So we often will show like a
spinner when something is is being
worked on, but in in a lot of cases the
it's so fast that it actually doesn't
make sense to show a loading indicator
that something is happening because it's
just like a split second where you're
showing that like like a quarter of a
spinner and that is kind of like a
weird janky UI, right? So what you can
do if you are showing a loader or using
like a react suspense or something like
that, throw a minimum display value on
that and if it does not need to show
like like basically you would render out
your loader but in the first 100
millisecond
uh life of that component show nothing
because in in an ideal circumstance you
you would go from your submission
submission state to your your finish
state and you don't have to show a
loader there cuz it's so quickly. Same
with like changing pages as well. When
you change from one page to another, it
often makes sense to show like a loading
bar um on the top. Like I had this with
my own website. I developed the whole
thing locally. I click on the page. It's
it's nice and fast. I have caching in in
production. It's nice and fast. But
there are some cases where maybe there's
no cache hit or maybe somebody's on a
really slow connection where you click
on something and nothing happens and and
you have you have to provide some sort
of like loading indicator that the the
page has changed from one to another
because you can't make the little
browser thing spin. you can't, you know,
normally when you go from a a regular
HTML page to another HTML page, you can
you can make the browser spin, but when
you're using a single page app and
you're using push state, you're not
actually reloading the the page. So, you
have to show the user that something is
happening. So, I'm I'm telling you both
show the user that something is
happening, but don't show them too
quickly because if it is a very fast
application, maybe you don't even need
to. The way they know that it worked is
that it literally worked. Yes. Right.
Totally. Exactly. Um, another good tip
here is preload on hover. So you can
have an event to listen for on hover,
then fire off your API call, whatever
that may be. Uh, many frameworks that
like take over data loading do this for

that when you hover over a link, it's

one of the things that people really

I'm over it. Uh that's that's how I

Yeah, that also comes with some some

It could be expensive for your actual
